Award.AwardTitle: IREU Site: Building Networks for U.S. and International Materials Science Undergraduates in Singapore, Scotland, and Italy
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award from the National Science Foundation Division of Materials Research (NSF DMR) supports a new international Research Experiences for Undergraduates (IREU) program organized and managed by the American Chemical Society (ACS) for the summers of 2014-2016. This IREU takes a non-traditional approach by connecting U.S. students with undergraduate research experiences throughout Europe and Asia while reciprocally, at no cost to US National funding agencies, international students will be placed into summer U.S. Materials Research REU sites. For 2014-2016, partner institutions include the National University of Singapore (NUS), the Universita degli Studi di Perugia (Italy), and the University of Strathclyde (Scotland, UK) all offering substantial research projects with a high potential for resulting publications. Nine U.S. students from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and from institutions with limited access to research (three to each international site) will be recruited nationally to participate in this ten-week IREU program. Conversely, international students from the three international sites are placed throughout existing NSF DMR sponsored REU programs in the U.S., nurturing the global networks of these domestic programs. Participants are matched with research mentors and projects with a focus on materials science for sustainable energy. All IREU participants present their research at the Spring American Chemical Society National Meeting; prepare an official abstract; create and present a research poster; consider ethical issues of research; gain respect for scientific professionalism, other cultures, and collaboration; and communicate scientific findings. The site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The globalization of science requires students to graduate with practical laboratory experiences, multicultural understanding, and an international perspective in order to compete in the global marketplace. All three are abilities that U.S. employers feel are lacking in the current crop of recent graduates (2008 Association of American Colleges and Universities employer survey). Clearly, a need exists to improve these skills but the rigorous course load for students in materials science-related degrees makes it difficult to study abroad during the academic year. Summer research allows students to gain international experience without disrupting their studies; increases national competiveness, innovation, and knowledge base; and assists in solving challenges of a global scope (e.g., energy, health, food/water). The ACS international research experiences for undergraduates (IREU) program funded by the National Science Foundation Division of Materials Research (DMR) yearly connects nine U.S. materials science students, recruited nationally from diverse backgrounds and institutions, with research experiences at recognized producers of scientific knowledge in Singapore; Glasgow, Scotland; and Perugia, Italy. While fostering intellectual growth and maturity, the IREU experience is intended to catalyze student's desire to enroll in advanced degree programs, instill a respect for other cultures and science professionalism, and provide an appreciation for the global scientific enterprise. Reciprocally, at no cost to U.S. institutions or funders, international students are matched to and placed at domestic DMR sponsored REU sites to nurture international dimensions and establish additional networks at these host universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2014-2017, the ACS IREU program placed 27 talented U.S. undergraduate chemistry and materials research students in respected labs in Italy, Singapore and the United Kingdom. Selected students had the opportunity to engage in research in an international context while enhancing their research abilities. IRES students came from all over the United States (including Puerto Rico) from large and smaller institutions alike and conducted research in topics from gold nanoparticles for novel drug delivery, utilizing more sustainable elements in the production of solar energy to quantum dots. IREU students undertook diverse research opportunities to learn new techniques and have exposure to a broader network of scientists in their field of research. 

 ACS partnered with the University of Perugia (Italy), National University of Singapore, and Strathclyde University (Scotland, United Kingdom) to make this project a success.

 The ACS IREU program produced a number of valuable outcomes for IREU students. One student, R. Warnock received the prestigious Erasmus Mundus Scholarship for a European Master’s program in France, Poland and Spain due in-part to her IREU experience in Italy. The ACS IREU DMR program has a high success rate of students continuing into chemistry/materials research field-as of this report, all 27 students from 2014-16 continue to scientific research in graduate school or work in industry. This program also has a high success rate of manuscripts submitted with 42% of DMR IREU students co-authoring manuscripts as part of their research experience. As of this report, three additional IREU students intend to publish their work in an appropriate research journal.

As part of their experience, all IREU students attend and present their scientific and cultural findings at the spring ACS National Meeting. Three joint symposiums were organized in 2015, 2016 and 2017 and attended by members of the chemistry and materials research communities. IREU students have the opportunity to learn from seasoned researchers outside of their home institution while experiencing a large scientific meeting.

The IREU experience provides participants with a unique opportunity to research and learn new cultural skills simultaneously. IREU students reported increased confidence in working with scientists from around the world as well as enhanced knowledge of their field of research and new techniques. Global scientific collaboration is not a choice in today's research environment, but rather a requirement for success. The IREU program enables the U.S. scientific community to prepare its trainees for a future with a strong international foundation that encourages collaboration while providing new opportunity for learning skills and techniques in the field of materials research.
